head.title: When the Trash Heap Is a Gold Mine

hedline.hl1: When the Trash Heap Is a Gold Mine

abstract.p: Elizabeth Laurino letter reports she has made tidy sum from selling what others discard

block.p: Re ''There's Treasure in Those Hills: Studies of Trash Show It Can Say a Lot About Values, Power, Sex'' (Arts & Ideas pages, June 17):

I am a ''discardiologist.'' (My terminology; I needed a title.) I have made a tidy sum of money selling what others discard. Vintage items like weather vanes, artwork, scrimshaw and taxidermy are just some of the treasures I have found.
Re ''There's Treasure in Those Hills: Studies of Trash Show It Can Say a Lot About Values, Power, Sex'' (Arts & Ideas pages, June 17):

I am a ''discardiologist.'' (My terminology; I needed a title.) I have made a tidy sum of money selling what others discard. Vintage items like weather vanes, artwork, scrimshaw and taxidermy are just some of the treasures I have found.

I can make some fairly accurate observations about the state of the economy. One can ascertain the health of the current wealth by the number of remodeling and/or redecorating discards on the curb. These are not inexpensive projects.

In addition, the general willingness to throw away potential collectibles and useful but out-of-style items signifies a confident economy. A bit wasteful, but those who do it are wealthy enough not to notice.
I thank the nouveaux riches and the stock market. Their willingness to throw out what others want to buy has given birth to a cottage industry and has helped finance my purchase of a vintage Porsche.
